Comment: I skimmed the article just to see if Booker had anything of substance to say and found this:  > **How did being in Israel on Oct. 7 influence your view on the war in Gaza, and your support for arms sales to Israel?**  > We were going over to meet with Palestinian leaders in the West Bank, because the Saudis were really close to normalizing [relations]. The irony of it — and this is probably pride coming before the fall — but we were talking with this real sense of joy that, for the first time in our lives, we saw a real pathway to a two-state solution. [Benjamin] Netanyahu, we really believed, was going to be boxed in because he desperately wanted normalization with the Saudis — which was the big win — but the only pathway was to commit to an irrevocable path to a two-state solution. That’s what we went over there feeling really excited about.   > When I left, after the horrors of that day — basically, the State Department surrounded us with security folks and we were in and out of the bomb shelter, and they said, “We need to get out.” Since then, **it’s nothing short of a painful reality for my office and myself, seeing the ways Hamas is getting exactly what they want, which is the focus being on Israel as the villain, and not the focus on Hamas and what they’re doing, even today,** to quell people that are trying to protest against them.  Booker is sellout zionist scum. A fraud and a coward to his core.

Comment: Still a false equivalence, though.  I firmly believe that some Dems are literally controlled opposition, but only a handful of them.  As a whole it's the difference between incompetence and intentional malice.  The Dems can be reformed by primarying the problem politicians and can actually be coaxed into doing something good if there is enough public support for it, but the GOP are nothing but a force for evil, especially today.  Part of the problem with Democrats is that they're the catch-all party for anyone who isn't on board with the fascism or racism the GOP has been embracing for decades, so it's nearly impossible for Dems to agree on anything except that they're not Republicans.  The views are far too diverse among its members, and that includes the voters.  The reason there are so many centrist democrats is because there are a lot of centrist voters who are really conservatives and don't want change.  If the GOP were a true conservative party and not a fascist cult, many of them would probably be republicans, or at least vote for them.  This leaves the more progressive voters feeling disenfranchised by the party, because it's a lot easier to stop change than it is to cause it, and unless the entire party is on board there is no way to actually make it happen.  IMO this is why so many people don't vote, because they feel neither party represents them or is working to change our broken system in a way that would make things better.  One party wants to maintain the status quo, and the other is actively making it worse.  The Democratic party needs reform, badly, and it needs to find its identity and start to stand for something or it will continue to bleed voters as they become more and more disillusioned.  But maintaining the status quo is still better than heading full speed toward a cliff, so it absolutely matters who is in power.
Author: ProfessionalCraft983

Comment: Veterans’ Access to Care Through Choice, Accountability, and Transparency Act (2014) → Co-authored major reform bill after the VA scandal; expanded funding and allowed veterans to access private health care if VA wait times were too long.  Veterans’ Compensation Cost-of-Living Adjustment Act (2013) → Ensured veterans’ disability compensation and other related benefits kept pace with inflation.  Amendment to increase funding for community health centers (as part of the Affordable Care Act, 2010) → Sanders fought to secure billions in extra funding to expand low-income community health centers nationwide.  Amendments for greater transparency at the Federal Reserve (as part of Dodd-Frank, 2010) → Sanders successfully pushed for a historic audit of the Fed to reveal details of emergency lending during the financial crisis.  Other Amendment — inserting important provisions into big bills (like capping CEO pay during the bailout).  Now will you take the same time I did to answer my question or do you intend to change the subject again? I would love to see you argue how fighting for Veterans isn't meaningful.
Author: RobTheThrone

Comment: Veterans’ Access to Care Through Choice, Accountability, and Transparency Act (2014) → This was indeed signed into law (Public Law No: 113-146), not just left in committee. It was a major bipartisan veterans’ reform bill after the VA wait-time scandal.  Veterans’ Compensation Cost-of-Living Adjustment Act (2013) → This also became law (Public Law No: 113-52), ensuring veterans’ benefits kept up with inflation.  Amendments for community health centers and Federal Reserve transparency → These were amendments, not standalone bills, but amendments can absolutely become law if they’re attached to larger passed legislation (like the Affordable Care Act or Dodd-Frank). Sanders did successfully push an amendment to audit the Fed’s emergency lending during the financial crisis, which passed.  So, the claim that these are “just in committee” or “performative” misrepresents that some of these were actually passed and had real effects, even if many Sanders-sponsored standalone bills did fail (which is common for many senators, especially those with outsider politics).  I can link to the laws themselves if you can't use Google to find things that don't confirm your bias. Now are you going to answer my original question or will you continue to gaslight?
Author: RobTheThrone
